**Yes, €200 per day is enough to feed 3 people lunch and dinner in Rome and Venice.** You can find plenty of good restaurants in both cities that offer affordable meals. Here are some tips on how to stretch your budget:

* **Avoid tourist traps.** The most expensive restaurants in Rome and Venice are often the ones that are located in the most popular tourist areas. If you're looking for a good value, try to find restaurants that are off the beaten path.
* **Look for lunch specials.** Many restaurants in Rome and Venice offer lunch specials that are much cheaper than their dinner menus. You can often get a main course, side dish, and drink for around €10-€15.
* **Share dishes.** If you're not that hungry, you can share a main course between two people. This is a great way to save money and try new dishes.
* **Order tap water.** Bottled water is very expensive in Italy, so it's best to order tap water instead. Most restaurants will serve it for free.

Here are some specific examples of meals that you could get for €200 per day in Rome and Venice:

* **Lunch:**
* Pizza: €8-€10
* Pasta: €10-€15
* Sandwich: €5-€7
* Salad: €5-€8
* **Dinner:**
* Pasta with meat or seafood: €15-€20
* Pizza: €10-€15
* Risotto: €15-€20
* Steak: €20-€30

Of course, you could spend more or less than €200 per day on food, depending on your preferences. If you want to eat at the very best restaurants, you'll obviously be spending more. Hi everyone!

First off, my husband and I would like to thank everyone in this group for sharing all of the tips and recommendations because it helped us tremendously in planning our Italy dream trip! Now we would love to share our tips, recommendations, and experiences to hopefully help someone else with their planning!

Our itinerary: June 28th-July 11th
Packages booked through Priceline

Flights- ATL-Venice June 28th-29th (Direct flight)

First stop: Venice June 29th-July 1st 📍
Shared water taxi from airport to hotel (GetYourGuide booking)

Accommodations: Hotel Dona Palace

Tours: Doge's Palace & St. Mark's Basilica with Terrace Access Tour

Restaurants:
Ristorante Centrale Pizzeria
Ristorante La Piazza

1000 Gourmet Venezia

Suso Gelato

Second stop: Florence July 1st-July 4th 📍

Accommodations: Grand Hotel Cavour

Tours & Activities:
Tuscany Day Trip from Florence:
Siena, San Gimignano, Pisa and Lunch at a Winery (Viator)

Restaurants:
Paoli Antico Ristorante Dal 1827
Gustapizza
Gelateria dei Neri
Auditore Ristorante Braceria
All'Antico Vinaio
Osteria Belle Donne - Wine Window

Third stop: Rome July 4th-July 7th 📍Accommodations: UnaHotels Decò Roma

Tours & Activities:
Twilight Trastevere Rome Food Tour (Eating Europe)
Colosseum, Roman Forum & Palatine Hill Guided Tour (Viator)
Vatican Museums, Sistine Chapel, & St. Peter's Basilica Guided Tour (Viator)

Restaurants:
Ristorante la Nuova Piazzetta
Oro Bistrot Cocktails
Ai Tre Scalini
Pastasciutta
Osteria da Fortunata
Mr. 100 Tiramisu

Fourth stop: Amalfi July 7th-July 10th 📍
Accomendations: Hotel Luna Convento

Tours & Activities:
Boat tour to Li Galli islands and Capri from Amalfi (YouKnowBoat)

Restaurants:
La Veranda
Ristorante L'Abside
Torre Saracena
Pasticceria Pansa

Fifth & Final Stop: Back to Venice (July 10-11th) 📍
Accommodations: Hotel Monaco & Grand Canal

Flights: Venice-Amsterdam / 1 h layover / Amsterdam-ATL July 11th

Apps:
Trenitalia - Trains
** Book early! Cheaper tickets and better options for seat selection. We did business class for each train
The Fork - Restaurant reservations
**We did about 40% reservations. Many did not take reservations. Arrive at 7:30-8pm and there is minimal wait time to be seated
Google Translate: the image feature was so helpful in translating menus

Phone: We did the AT&T $10 International day pass and it worked fantastic! No issues the entire time

Currency: We only took $400 euros with us that I had ordered through our bank. It was perfect for us because many places took credit card. We have the Capitol One Venture card which has a zero transaction fee internationally.

Pickpocketing: no issue but we both took precautions with our front crossbodies

Packing: We each only took a backpack and carryon. Packing cubes were a life saver! I got 20 outfits in one cube. Personally, I strongly advise packing lighter because of all the walking.
*** Essential items: Front crossbody, portable iPhone charger, tide pens, RFID passport wallet, sunscreen, collapsible water bottle, and comfortable shoes

Hiccups: Every trip has them right? Well on our way from Florence to Rome on the train, my husband and I accidentally got off at the wrong stop…. But not only that, I left my crossbody bag (which had my passport, credit cards, drivers license, and money) in the train seat. After a minor panic attack we went to the ticket office where an employee was able to call the train and locate my bag. I was able to get it back 4 hours later!

******Research, research, and more research! I can’t say enough how doing researchprior to our trip was so important. We were able to be present in the moment and really make the most of the time we had. Also, only scheduling one activity per day and setting time aside for breaks was life saving.

It truly was a trip of a lifetime ❤️
